sub: /sqg/ - Squatter General
com:
>What is /sqg/?
In the course of human events, economic calmaties may force innocent people out of their homes. /sqg/ seeks to provide those willing with a viable alternative to the cold, harsh life of living on the streets, as well as a platform for discussion of squatting.

>What is squatting?
Squatting(for our purposes) is the act of residing in a residence unbeknownst to anybody living there, and partially subsisting off stealing from legal residents. For some, squatting may be much more preferable to the typical homeless lifestyle, as it guarantees food, water, electricity, and shelter.

>How do I get started?
1. Choose a home. Homes with elderly citizens, few residents, and/or residents who frequently leave the house are easy pickings. For your first squat, try to avoid homes with a family as the more residents live there, the more likely you will be discovered. Furthermore, large homes tend to have better hiding spots than smaller ones.
2. Perform a reconnaissance break-in. This initial break-in is crucial as it will allow you to find hiding spots and escape routes and determine how much and what materials you should bring. A guide with a few examples of hiding spots is the attached image on this thread. Choose a time when nobody's home so you can take a complete tour of the home. Repeat Steps 1 and 2 until you are satisfied with the home you have chosen.
3. Move in. Pretty self-explanatory but it should be noted that this process may take longer than you think, especially if you are bringing a lot of supplies with you. Speaking of supplies, I'd recommend at the barest minimum a sleeping bag, flashlight, smell-proof container, lock-picking apparatus, and some sort of weapon should the worst come to worst. Ideally, moving in should be done at night while the residents are asleep.

sub: Liar in life
com:
1.5 years ago, I dropped out of college. I did not tell my parents immediately, because I knew they would be disappointed, and I had no good excuse.

Every opportunity I set for myself to come clean, I couldn't do it, they continued to believe I was in school. As time went on, it became harder and harder to tell the truth. To maintain the lie, I even kept up the false image to my friends, roommates, everyone. I got a job in a factory to support myself. The only people who I was honest to have been coworkers there and a handful of complete strangers.

Eventually I determined I could avoid the fallout of the lie by following a new career path, something they could understand dropping college for. I dedicated myself to entering this sort-of technical school for a niche trade. I spent money and studied to prepare myself for it. I bet it all, and it failed. I was not admitted. By this point I hated my factory job, and decided to quit anyway, even though I had nowhere to go.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27865983

Look up the concept of an "extinction burst." Basically any time you try to change a behavior, especially an addictive one, your psychology will throw one last heave-ho at you because it prefers the old way. It's the comfortable, knowable, homeostatic option.

Your body fears the unknown, fears change, because it thinks that how you are right now is " working" but you know that's not true.

For context, I did super well in my GCSE's and A-levels, did crappy working holiday jobs for a year which were fine but I wanted to challenge myself. I signed up for a degree, I'm 3 months in and I'm just not interested. I just can't find the passion for any high level subject and the 'uni experience' mostly consists of pub crawls and overpriced mediocre sports clubs and rushed in person or old powerpoint online lectures. I was looking into doing a working holiday in the USA over the summer as an outdoors instructor (I have an interview for tomorrow). I'm tempted to drop out and start jobs/ courses that offer employment and qualifications in that field. However, the courses and apprenticeships seem to be for bottom feeding 90IQ retards, and none of the jobs offer live-in accommodation. There's a course which meets the requirements, but starts in a years time and I've got a year plus to make use of my time in. Is there any other jobs which require some skill and intelligence but you don't need Uni for? I'm not even saying I'm smart, but I don't want to spend a year on the same level with people who can barely add numbers up. My sisters are major high achievers, and although my parents say 'I can do whatever makes me happy blah blah blah, its shallow BS (they've proven it to be so before). And I don't want to labelled an embarrassment to my family.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27864740
There are summer research courses that act as a school semester in the United states where you live in an outdoor research station for example

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27864740
Hiking guide if in a good location and you are in shape. States like colorado, texas, california, etc somewhere with enough mountains but enough cities for travel to have steady income.

I live in texas hill country doing remote work but notice a lot of jobs for camps or resort inns by rivers offering work (some seasonal) and live in accommodations. Given your skills could be worth it. Mostly maintenance work so expect it would help if you have experience in that kinda home improvement handyman skills.

I would look into forestry internships. Or internships at national parks or even a local parks and rec.

sub: Depressed about small family
com:
>be me, 19
most of my older family and my father/entire father's side is dead, the rest of my family members are dispersed all over the country in different states from me. I always kind of wished I was part of a big family, how the fuck do I fix this empty hole inside of me? Should I just get friends? would having a bunch of kids work? Should I just try to date someone with a big family?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
It's natural to want to be part of a big family, but there are many other ways to feel connected and loved.
For example, you could try to build close relationships with friends, pursue hobbies and interests that bring you joy, and volunteer or get involved in your community.
But none of this is a "just do it" action. It will take time and you may not like some of the people you meet.
But in the end, you can choose your friends, but you can't choose your family. Use that as a positive.

>>27864049
>hypocritical and self-defeating as a justification.
Bingo bango bongo. And this was key to overcoming my ASPD, granted it wasn’t an a-ha! moment with a flick of a switch change overnight. It takes a long while to shed the asshole. But yes—this is the self-perpetuating cycle that breathes constant life into the disorder. It’s a feedback loop. And it’s entirely perpetrated by the ASPD person themselves unwittingly.
How the hell can anyone who isn’t the person(s) who abused the ASPD know their whole backstory? They’re not psychic. Nor is it the responsibility of others to carry the legacy of hurt on their shoulders for the sake of a bpd, or an npd, or an aspd. It’s simply not doable and unfair to those around the sociopath. It certainly was to those around me.

And even IF you convince them—rationally—and they can understand it, intellectually? It doesn’t change. Because emotionally they are still stuck on it. This cognitive dissonance is so engulfing inside that it leads to relapse and repeated cycles of ASPD. And they can see it yet simultaneously feel 100% unable to ‘stop it’. Which seems ridiculous to everyone on the outside.
Just as it seems ridiculous to watch a child be unable to prevent its emotions taking over. Same shit literally. Personality disorders occur from a developmental arrest. They have the emotional capabilities of a 4 - 7 year old, but the intellect of an adult. The trauma and upbringing did that.

Now—I raised the parts of me my parents failed in. Took me decades but here I am. My main point is this: If you encounter one? Walk away. No contact. Get out of dodge. That’s all you gotta do. You owe them nothing.

But do not mercilessly return hate for hate. Because that is EXACTLY what an ASPD like me would have wanted. It justifies our whole entire bullshit. If you really want to fuck them and indirectly “help” them? You help yourself by cutting them out and keeping a mile away.
